thread.title: Seven police officers accused of beating Occupy activist Ken Tsang convicted of assault
thread.title_full: Seven police officers accused of beating Occupy activist Ken Tsang convicted of assault | South China Morning Post

author: Jasmine Siu, Eddie Lee
title: Seven police officers accused of beating Occupy activist Ken Tsang convicted of assault
text:
Seven police officers were on Tuesday convicted of kicking, punching and stepping on activist Ken Tsang Kin-chiu after he was arrested and handcuffed for assaulting police during an Occupy protest more than two years ago.
The seven accused are Chief Inspector Wong Cho-shing, 50; Senior Inspector Lau Cheuk-ngai, 31; Detective Sergeant Pak Wing-bun, 43; police constable Lau Hing-pui, 39; and detective police constables Wong Wai-ho, 38; Chan Siu-tan, 33; and Kwan Ka-ho, 33.
All seven originally faced one joint count of causing grievous bodily harm with intent, of which they were found not guilty. They were instead convicted of a lesser charge of assault occasioning actual bodily harm.
Chan was also convicted of an additional charge of common assault.
The seven have been remanded.

Dozens of the policemen’s supporters watching a live broadcast in an adjacent courtroom clapped their hands in delight when they heard an interpreter say that the seven were acquitted of the first charge.
But their joy proved fleeting as they learned of the guilty verdicts on the second and third charges and they immediately lapsed into silence.
Judge David Dufton’s verdict concludes one of the most controversial cases arising from the pro-democracy civil disobedience movement in 2014, when thousands took over major thoroughfares for up to 79 days following Beijing’s announcement of a restrictive political reform framework.
Occupy activist Ken Tsang’s injuries ‘almost certainly’ inflicted by police baton, Hong Kong court told 
The District Court previously heard Tsang, 41, testify that he had poured liquid onto officers on a clearance operation in Admiralty and was brought to a nearby substation by a group of officers after he was arrested and zip-tied.
The 224-page judgment found Tsang was carried to the substation where he was dumped on the ground and immediately assaulted, leaving him with injuries to his face, neck, shoulder, flank, chest and back.
However, the court was not satisfied that these injuries amounted to grievous bodily harm.
As to the charge of common assault, Chan was convicted after the court accepted Tsang’s identification of the officer in a direct confrontation.
The activist had claimed that Chan slapped his face twice in the report room at Central Police Station.
Video may not show Ken Tsang being beaten, accused Hong Kong police officers claim 
At issue was whether Tsang was assaulted by any or all of the seven officers.
The defence had countered that none of the accused were equipped with the specific baton that could have left certain bruises on the activist and argued that news footage could not be relied on for identification due to its poor quality.
Tsang was jailed for five weeks in a separate trial at Kowloon City Court last May over one count of assaulting police and two of resisting police.
He was immediately released on bail, pending an appeal against his conviction.
